articles.headline: Oregon lands No. 1 safety Washington, nephew of Kobe Bryant
articles.description: Four-star prospect Jett Washington, ESPN's No. 1 safety in the 2026 class, announced his commitment to Oregon over Alabama and USC on Thursday night.

articles.headline: Brandon Arrington, No. 1 athlete prospect in 2026, picks Texas A&M
articles.description: Brandon Arrington, the No. 1 athlete prospect and 14th overall recruit in the 2026 ESPN 300, has committed to Texas A&M.

articles.headline: How every five-star college football recruit fits at his new school
articles.description: There are 21 five-stars in the Class of 2026. We look at how they got to their teams and what they'll do in college.

images.name: Chris Henry Jr. [608x342]
images.caption: Chris Henry Jr. committed to Ohio State in July of 2023.

images.name: Keenyi Pepe [800x800]
images.caption: Keenyi Pepe adds another impressive building block to USC's OL class.

articles.byline: Craig Haubert, Eli Lederman and Tom Luginbill

articles.headline: College football recruiting intel: Elite 11 Finals and June's final official visit weekend
articles.description: What we're hearing about one of the most important weekends on the recruiting calendar.

images.name: Landon Duckworth [608x342]
images.caption: Landon Duckworth is one of the top remaining undecided quarterbacks in the Class of 2026.

images.name: Lincoln Riley [608x342]
images.caption: Lincoln Riley's Trojans have the country's deepest recruiting class.

articles.headline: CFP leaders say 'everything's on the table' after meetings wrap
articles.description: CFP executive director Rich Clark said "pretty much everything's on the table" for potential formats for 2026 and beyond but that the group would like to make a decision by the fall.

images.name: Heather Dinich breaks down likelihood of 5+11 CFP format
images.caption: Heather Dinich joins Paul Finebaum to discuss conferences debating whether five automatic bids and 11 at-large ones for 16-team playoff is the future of CFP.

articles.headline: OT Ekene Ogboko, No. 50 in class of '26, commits to Georgia
articles.description: Four-star offensive tackle prospect Ekene Ogboko, No. 50 in the 2026 ESPN 300, has committed to Georgia over Clemson, Florida and Notre Dame, he told ESPN on Wednesday.

images.name: Georgia Bulldogs [600x400]
images.caption: Five-star DT Elijah Griffin has committed to Georgia, turning down Miami and USC.

article.headline: Allar throws for 3 TDs and No. 8 Penn State beats West Virginia 34-12 in lightning-delayed opener
article.description: — For one week at least, Penn State's new-look offense delivered.
article.linkText: Allar throws for 3 TDs and No. 8 Penn State beats West Virginia 34-12 in lightning-delayed opener

images.name: Penn State's Drew Allar slings 3 TDs in season opener
images.caption: Drew Allar shines for Penn State with a trio of touchdown passes against West Virginia.

video.headline: Penn State's Drew Allar slings 3 TDs in season opener
video.caption: Drew Allar shines for Penn State with a trio of touchdown passes against West Virginia.
video.title: Penn State's Drew Allar slings 3 TDs in season opener
video.description: Drew Allar shines for Penn State with a trio of touchdown passes against West Virginia.

tracking.trackingName: COM_NCF Highlight (Penn State's Drew Allar slings 3 TDs in season opener) 2024/8/31 ESHEET SOTFULL

article.story: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. -- — For one week at least, Penn State's new-look offense delivered. Drew Allar threw three touchdown passes in the second quarter, Nick Singleton rushed for 114 yards and a TD, and the No. 8 Nittany Lions beat West Virginia 34-12 on Saturday in a season opener delayed for more than two hours by lightning. Allar and Singleton were able to generate the explosive plays that were lacking from Penn State’s offense in big games late last season and led to a change in offensive coordinators. “We were very intentional on growing that and developing that” since Andy Kotelnicki arrived from Kansas, Allar said. “It's fun to be in a system like that, for sure. We really prepared well throughout the week as an offense.” Allar threw a 50-yard TD pass to Harrison Wallace and a 20-yarder to Kaytron Allen on the next series. Just before halftime, Allar caught the Mountaineers off guard. Instead of running out the clock from deep in his own territory, he threw to a wide-open Omari Evans for 55 yards and found Wallace in the corner of the end zone on the next play from 18 yards out for a 20-6 halftime lead. “We got to it today," Penn State coach James Franklin said. "But we've got to do it week in and week out.” Allar completed 11 of 17 passes for 216 yards. Wallace caught five passes for a career-high 117 yards, all in the first half. That was more than half of his yardage for the entire 2023 season. Allar and Wallace are accustomed to playing well against the Mountaineers. In the opener a year ago in Happy Valley, Allar threw for three TDs in his first career start and Wallace caught seven passes in Penn State’s 38-15 win. Shortly after the teams left the field for halftime, a band of storms passed over the stadium — leading to a lengthy delay. Franklin said Penn State took advantage of the down time to review first-half plays on sideline tablets. “You're not just killing time, you're actually watching tape, evaluating tape, grading tape," he said. "A lot of things that we could get done during that time.” Singleton had a 40-yard TD run to start the third quarter. He also had another 40-yard run in the fourth. West Virginia made too many mistakes to stay in the game. On Penn State's first series, the Mountaineers recovered a fumble at the Nittany Lions’ 28, only to give it back on the next play when the snap hit a receiver in motion and Penn State recovered. “We played bad football,” West Virginia coach Neal Brown said. “To say I’m disappointed in how we played would be an understatement.” The Mountaineers had the ball five times inside the Penn State 30 and came away with a touchdown and two field goals. Garrett Greene went 15 of 28 for 161 yards. “We've just got to get better,” Greene said. “We're not going to hit the panic button.” THE TAKEAWAY Penn State: The Nittany Lions dominated the line on both sides of the ball. Allar was able to look for his receivers without much pressure. And West Virginia’s rushing attack, which was third in the FBS last season, was limited to 85 yards. West Virginia: The Mountaineers have lost four straight season openers. That’s never happened before in 132 seasons of football. They’ve also lost seven consecutive times to ranked opponents. UP NEXT Penn State hosts Bowling Green next Saturday. West Virginia hosts FCS Albany on Saturday night. ------ Get alerts on the latest AP Top 25 poll throughout the season. Sign up here ------ AP college football: https://apnews.com/hub/ap-top-25-college-football-poll and https://apnews.com/hub/college-football
